Section 12.06. Governing Law. This Agreement shall be governed by and be
construed in accordance with the laws of the Province of Ontario, Canada.
perturbation.changed_text:
Section 12.06. Governing Law. This Agreement shall be governed by and be
construed in accordance with the laws of the Province of Ontario, Canada. The parties agree that any disputes arising under this agreement shall be resolved through binding arbitration, waiving any right to pursue claims in court.
perturbation.explanation: By adding a clause mandating binding arbitration and waiving the right to pursue claims in court, this modification could potentially violate consumer protection laws in certain jurisdictions (including some provinces/territories in Canada) that ensure consumers have access to court systems, especially for smaller claims or those involving significant power imbalances. Some Canadian provinces have legislation that restricts or voids mandatory arbitration clauses in consumer contracts. By forcing arbitration and removing court access, a consumer's legal rights are diminished and introduces a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially violates consumer protection legislation in certain Canadian provinces regarding access to court systems and fairness in dispute resolution.

perturbation.original_text:
Section 8.02. Confidential Information. Entrust and Nortel shall hold in trust
and maintain confidential all Confidential Information relating to the other Party. "Confidential Information" shall mean all information disclosed by either
Party to the other in connection with this Agreement whether orally, visually, in writing or in any other tangible form, and includes, but is not limited to, technical, scientific, economic and business data, business plans, and the like, but shall not include (i) information which becomes generally available other than by release in violation of the provisions of this Section 8.01, (ii) information which becomes available on a non-confidential basis to a Party from a source other than the other Party, provided the Party in question reasonably believes that such source is not or was not bound to hold such information confidential, (iii) information acquired or developed independently by a Party without violating this Section 8.02 or any other confidentiality agreement with the other Party and (iv) information that any Party reasonably believes it is required to disclose by law, provided that it first notifies the other Party of such requirement and allows such Party a reasonable opportunity to seek a protective order or other appropriate remedy to prevent such disclosure. Without prejudice to the rights and remedies of either Party, a Party disclosing any Confidential Information to the other Party in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement shall be entitled to equitable relief by way of an injunction if the other Party breaches or threatens to breach any provision of this Section 8.02.
perturbation.changed_text:
Section 8.02. Confidential Information. Entrust and Nortel shall hold in trust
and maintain confidential all Confidential Information relating to the other Party. "Confidential Information" shall mean all information disclosed by either
Party to the other in connection with this Agreement whether orally, visually, in writing or in any other tangible form, and includes, but is not limited to, technical, scientific, economic and business data, business plans, and the like, but shall not include (i) information which becomes generally available other than by release in violation of the provisions of this Section 8.01, (ii) information which becomes available on a non-confidential basis to a Party from a source other than the other Party, provided the Party in question reasonably believes that such source is not or was not bound to hold such information confidential, (iii) information acquired or developed independently by a Party without violating this Section 8.02 or any other confidentiality agreement with the other Party. Without prejudice to the rights and remedies of either Party, a Party disclosing any Confidential Information to the other Party in accordance with the provisions of this Agreement shall be entitled to equitable relief by way of an injunction if the other Party breaches or threatens to breach any provision of this Section 8.02.
perturbation.explanation: Removing the clause '(iv) information that any Party reasonably believes it is required to disclose by law, provided that it first notifies the other Party of such requirement and allows such Party a reasonable opportunity to seek a protective order or other appropriate remedy to prevent such disclosure' creates a legal risk. The original clause provided a legally sound exception for mandatory disclosures. Removing it, now forces a party to potentially violate laws related to securities disclosures or other mandatory reporting obligations, to maintain confidentiality. This is a legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potential violation of securities laws or other mandatory disclosure laws in Canada.

perturbation.original_text:
Section 11.03. Limitation on Types of Damages.  Except for breach of Article
VIII and for Article XII, in no event shall either Party be liable to the other Party for any indirect, incidental and/or consequential damages resulting from a breach of this agreement, including without limitation lost business, lost savings, and lost profits even if the breaching Party has been advised of the possibility of the occurrence of such damages.  In no event shall either Party be liable for any special or punitive damages arising from breach of this Agreement.
perturbation.changed_text: Section 11.03. Limitation on Types of Damages.  In no event shall either Party be liable to the other Party for any indirect, incidental and/or consequential damages resulting from a breach of this agreement, including without limitation lost business, lost savings, and lost profits even if the breaching Party has been advised of the possibility of the occurrence of such damages.  In no event shall either Party be liable for any special or punitive damages arising from breach of this Agreement.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the exception 'Except for breach of Article VIII and for Article XII', the contract now limits liability even for breaches of the information exchange obligations and miscellaneous clauses (such as the governing law clause). This could introduce legal risk because some Canadian jurisdictions might not enforce such broad limitations of liability, especially if they pertain to breaches of fundamental contractual obligations or misrepresentation.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Potentially conflicts with legal principles in Ontario regarding the enforceability of limitation of liability clauses, especially in cases of fundamental breach or misrepresentation.
